title: Got quest called "Teach a Friend" Anyone else?
body:
As mentioned by the title, when I logged in this morning, I saw a quest called "Teach a Friend" that asked me to win a bot game with a player that is level 15 or under in my party for the "Good Pals icon" and 200 blue essence. 

Anyone else got this quest or know why i specifically got it. 

btw- honor 4: checkpoint 3, gold 5, and level 100 if anyone is wondering.






Edit: From everyone's experiences with this quest, it appears that it is a universal quest that everyone will get. 
Also, there's a quest afterward that gives you a hextech chest for killing dragon and baron with a low level friend.

replies.body: And so Riot tries to turn the missions into a recruiting tool. This is an indicator that League is worse off than it has been in a long time.

i mean..  I dont think it means LoL is in the dumps. I think this is more of an experiement.

idk if youve noticed but Riot really REALLY wants LoL to be a social platform and a TON of changes reflect that.
Sharing Match History on FaceBook or somecrap.
Riot literally forcing Flex Que.
Allowing people to still chat while on their mobile (seriously wtf).
adding in Clubs.
replacing RGM with Clash which is basically just Flex Que with rewards.

Riot has always understood that a playing with friends can make just about anything fun it keeps people coming back for goodtimes as a kinda makeshift way to "hang out" with one another.

The difference is that none of those examples were designed to recruit *new* players, they were ways for existing players to interact with existing players. 

There's a point when players are starting out in League where they're thinking "This is fun, I want my friends to play this with me!". That gradually transitions to "The learning curve is too great, and my friends would have to go through too much toxicity to even get to a point I could really play with them. It's not worth it to invite them." 

This mission is trying to encourage players who are on the fence about inviting friends to do it for an icon and some BE. It's trying to win out over the second mentality by appealing to a player's desire to get free stuff.

A useless icon and 200 BE lol give em a free skin for freak sakes

They tried that with Gray Warwick and Medieval Twitch back when the referral program was a thing. According to Riot, most people got those skins as a result of more smurf/bot accounts than actual new players. As such they're probably trying to find a less enticing (but still enticing) reward.
What about it is "makeshift"?  Playing games together is a great time.

Disagree with the sentiment as well.  It's in any game's best interest to have new players come in, no matter what the game's status is.  Riot and League are still businesses first and foremost, no matter what anyone might say.  Doesn't mean anything's gone downhill.  

That said, obviously, nothing is forever, including League's status among games.  This, too, will end.

New players are good for business, giving out BE is bad (Riot would prefer people to buy things with RP). If you can get new players without spending BE you would prefer to do that - which is what Riot has done for many, many years. If Riot has to give BE to get new players it means that they're not getting enough new players. (Side note: BE for events is a little different, since they're doing that to keep players satisfied and coming back. A player that enjoys the game and comes back may spend money, a player who isn't satisfied and doesn't come back doesn't spend money.)

Now, you could argue that they increased their expectations on what's "enough new players", but that's unlikely considering the age of the game. You expect to not gain as many new players when your game is nearly 10 years old. That leaves the other interpretation, which is that they have noticed a dip in new players/new player retention, below what they predicted, and are looking to correct it.

Eh, yes and no.  

MMOs are generally most fun when you are playing with friends so I'm guessing riot is trying to get everyone to be friends with people so they play more and enjoy the game more.  _Now there certainly could be other ulterior motives_, but this might also be a harmless incentive.

You're not wrong, but most games don't need to tell you "go out and get a friend to play in the next 2 weeks." *League of Legends* didn't need to tell people to do that. Something has changed to make Riot think that they need something like this.
That's a fair assessment.  Without proof either way, who can say?

Why does everyone assume anything a billion dollar company does has a hidden side goal that we can't see, and then they get viewed negatively for trying to have higher level players play with lower levels to make them better. Not to mention you get free loot.

What do you mean "We cant see".
Everyone can see that goal quite clearly.

Because this is the Boards and every view not negative enough gets booted out.

I wish i was sarcastic, really

Everything they do _does_ have a "hidden" side-goal, and that is **to make money**.  
Really, why people imagine they should have any goal that supersedes this is confusing... rito is a business.

Care to tell me how higher level players find lower level players to play with? Was there a mentor system added? Was there a system added to help experienced players find inexperienced players? Were chat rooms re-added? 

In the absence of any support infrastructure, there's only one way to find and join a party with new players, so let's call this mission what it *really* is. 
"Get a new friend to play League of Legends."

There's nothing hidden about the mission and it's objective. What's hidden is what's happening to the player population that made Riot decide they needed this **now** when they haven't needed something like this for years.

Because it should be common knowledge that anything and everything a company does is to make money. The end goal of every company is to make money. How they go about that does play a part, but it's the money that matters. 

Hence, this mission is clearly attempting to get you to invite friends who haven't tried League into it (made even more obvious when you take into account the recent push for ads from Riot). 

Unfortunately, logic dictates you'd only invite your friends to a game you actually like and can see yourself being able to teach them without too much stress. League, especially in the current state, is not that kind of game. Their attempts are misguided, when all they really need is to make the game fun again-- at least for the kind of players who are vocal to their friends.

0. Anti-cheat goes live, making it harder to load up multiple accounts on virtual machines
0. Mandatory email verification goes live, making it harder to create multiple accounts
0. No way to find low-level players within the client
0. Mission to duo with a low-level player goes live

This mission would've been fine as a "recruit-a-friend" system that uses the existing "mission" mechanism, but putting unique rewards in a limited-time event shifts the focus from recruitment to completing a limited-time event in the most efficient way possible. This encourages alternating smurf matches with friends or just loading a smurf account on a spare PC.
